objtitle.title: *Exhibition of Paintings in Fresco, Poetical and Historical Inventions*

imprint.note: Bentley notes that Blake apparently sent this flyer to his friends in May 1809; the only surviving copies were folded into envelopes and sealed with a wafer. Copy A was addressed to Ozias Humphrey and accompanied by a letter from Blake (*Writings* volume 2, page 1692).

objinfo.numberleaves: 2 The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. The prospectus is printed on the first recto and first verso (Object 1 and 2, respectively), both of which include handwritten additions by Blake. This folded sheet was folded again to form a packet. The address appears on the second verso (Object 3), The blank second recto is not pictured.
objinfo.medium: type with handwritten additions in pen and ink

provenance.name: The Huntington Library, Art Museum, and Botanical Gardens

repository.institution: The Huntington Library, Art Museum, and Botanical Gardens

objtitle.title: Exhibition of Paintings in Fresco, Poetical and Historical Inventions

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. The prospectus is printed on the first recto and first verso (Object 1 and 2, respectively), both of which include handwritten additions by Blake. This folded sheet was folded again to form a packet. The address appears on the second verso (Object 3). The blank second recto is not pictured.

lg.l: EXHIBITION
OF
Poetical and Historical Inventions,
BY. WM.William Blake BLAKE.
THE ANCIENT BRITONS—Three Ancient Britons overthrowing the
Army of armed Romans; the Figures full as large as Life—
From the Welch Triades.
In the last Battle that Arthur fought, the most Beautiful was one
That return'dreturned, and the most Strong another: with them also return'dreturned
The most Ugly, and no other beside return'dreturned from the bloody Field.
The most Beautiful, the Roman Warriors trembled before and worshipped:
The most Strong, they melted before him and dissolved in his presence:
The most Ugly they fled with outcries and contortion of their Limbs.
THE CANTERBURY PILGRIMS from Chaucer—a cabinet Picture in
Fresco—Thirty Figures on Horse-backHorseback, in a brilliant Morning Scene.

lg.note: Bentley notes that in the *Descriptive Catalogue* the picture in question is described as having twenty-nine figures (*Writings* volume 2, page 821).
lg.l: Two Pictures, representing grand Apotheoses of NELSON and PITT,
with variety of cabinet Pictures, unchangeable and permanent in
Fresco, and Drawings for Public Inspection and for Sale by Private
Contract, at
No. 28, Corner of BROAD STREET, Golden-Square.
"Fit Audience find tho'though few" MILTON.
Admittance 2s. 6d. each Person, a discriptivedescriptive Catalogue included, ContainingBentley reads "discriptive" as "descriptive" (*Writings* volume 2, page 821).
————————Ample Illustrations This line is a double rule in the original text.
Watts & Co. Printers, Southmolton St.The abbreviation "St." at the end of this line is smeared. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 821) and Erdman (527) read it as "St."

l.note: Bentley notes that Blake added the words "Containing Ample Illustrations on Art" at the bottom of page in both surviving copies of the flyer (*Writings* volume 2, page 821).

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. The prospectus is printed on the first recto and first verso (Object 1 and 2, respectively), both of which include handwritten additions by Blake. This folded sheet was folded again to form a packet. The address appears on the second verso (Object 3). The blank second recto is not pictured.

l.hi: The Invention of a portable Fresco.

lg.l: A Wall on Canvas or Wood, or any other portable thing, of dimensions ever so large,
or ever so small, which may be removed with the same convenience as so many easel
Pictures; is worthy the consideration of the Rich and those who have the direction
of public Works. If the Frescos of APELLES, of PROTOGENES, of RAPHAEL, or

MICHAEL ANGELO Michelangelo
could have been removed, we might, perhaps, have them now
in England. I could divide Westminster Hall, or the walls of any other great
Building, into compartments and ornament them with Frescos, which would be
removable at pleasure.

Oil will not drink or absorb
Colour color enough to stand the test of very little Time and
of the Air; it grows yellow, and at length brown. It was never generally used till
after VANDYKEVan Dyke'S time. All the little old Pictures, called cabinet Pictures, are in
Fresco, and not in Oil.
Fresco Painting is properly Miniature, or Enamel Painting; every thing in Fresco
is as high finished as Miniature or Enamel, although in Works larger than Life.

The Art has been lost: I have recovered it. How this was done, will be told,
to- together

gether together
with the whole Process, in a Work on Art, now in the Press. The ignorant
Insults of Individuals will not hinder me from doing my duty to my Art. Fresco
Painting, as it is now practisedpracticed, is like most other things, the contrary of what it
pretends to be.
The execution of my Designs, being all in Water-colourscolors, (that is in Fresco) are
regularly refused to be exhibited by the Royal Academy, and the British Institution

has, this year, followed its example, and has effectually excluded me by this
Reso- Resolution

lutionResolution; I therefore invite those Noblemen and Gentleman, who are its Subscribers, toBentley reads "Gentleman" as "Gentlemen" (*Writings* volume 2, page 822). Erdman reads the same word as "Gentlem[e]n" (527).
inspect what they have excluded: and those who have been told that my Works
are but an unscientific and irregular Eccentricity, a Madman's Scrawls, I demand of
them to do me the justice to examine before they decide.
There cannot be more than two or three great Painters or Poets in any Age or
Country; and these, in a corrupt state of Society, are easily excluded, but not so

easily obstructed. They have exludedexcluded Water-colourscolors; it is therefore become neces- necessary
Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 822) and Erdman (528) read "exluded" as "ex[c]luded".

sary necessary
that I should exhibit to the Public, in an Exhibition of my own, my Designs,
Painted in Water-colourscolors. If Italy is enriched and made great by RAPHAEL, if MICHAEL Michelangelo

ANGELO Michelangelo
is its supreme glory, if Art is the glory of a Nation, if Genius and
Inspira- Inspiration

tion Inspiration
are the great Origin and Bond of Society, the distinction my Works have
ob- obtained

tained obtained
from those who best understand such things, calls for my
Exbibition Exhibition as theBentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 822) and Erdman (528) read "Exbibition" as "Exhibition".
greatest of Duties to my Country.
May 15. 1809WILLIAM BLAKE.

objnote.p: The full sheet was folded to form two leaves. The prospectus is printed on the first recto and first verso (Object 1 and 2, respectively), both of which include handwritten additions by Blake. This folded sheet was folded again to form a packet. The address appears on the second verso (Object 3). The blank second recto is not pictured.
